title: How to Make an Orca (Shachi) from a Plastic Straw

steps.headline: Note the terminology applying to each piece of the straw.
steps.description: This diagram shows how the pieces of the straw will be used to make the orca. The short end will be the tail, while the two long, thin pieces will be the stand (stick in the diagram) and the backbone. You'll fold the long, wide pieces to make the body of the orca. It might help you to print this off to follow. Additionally, you might want to use a straw with colored lines running down the side for your first try.

steps.headline: Locate the bend in the straw.
steps.description:
For now, keep the bend in the closed position. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Shachi2_122.JPG/460px-Shachi2_122.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Shachi2_122.JPG/759px-Shachi2_122.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Flatten the straw. Press down on each side of the bend to flatten the straw, running your fingers over the bend a few times. Do not flatten the bend itself.

steps.headline: Cut out the backbone and stand.
steps.description:
Pinch the straw flat between your thumb and forefinger with one hand. With the other hand, use scissors to cut out your first piece. With the straw flat, cut a thin strip off one side, making sure you cut both layers of the straw. (If you're using a lined straw, it might be useful to flatten the straw such that the thin backbone and stand pieces contain the lines.) {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Shachi4_183.JPG/460px-Shachi4_183.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Shachi4_183.JPG/758px-Shachi4_183.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Stop cutting when you reach the straw bend. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Shachi5_450.JPG/460px-Shachi5_450.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Shachi5_450.JPG/760px-Shachi5_450.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut out another thin strip on the other side of the flattened straw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Shachi6_929.JPG/460px-Shachi6_929.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Shachi6_929.JPG/759px-Shachi6_929.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Again, don't cut along the edge itself but right next to it. You should be cutting two layers of straw, not one. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi7_204.JPG/460px-Shachi7_204.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi7_204.JPG/759px-Shachi7_204.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}There will be four "sticks" once you're done with cutting – two thin sticks and two wide sticks.

steps.headline: Begin tying the body of the orca.
steps.description:
First, take one of the thin sticks and bend it so that it's at a 90-degree angle to the straw. This stick will be the stand. The other thin stick will be the backbone. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Shachi9_933.JPG/460px-Shachi9_933.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Shachi9_933.JPG/759px-Shachi9_933.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Grab one of the wide sticks and pull it under the backbone, then up and back down through the loop created. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Shachi10_891.JPG/460px-Shachi10_891.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Shachi10_891.JPG/759px-Shachi10_891.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Pull the knot created by the wide stick all the way up to the bend in the straw. Tug gently on the bottom of the wide stick to tighten.

steps.headline: Tie the other wide stick.
steps.description:
As with the first wide stick, pull it under the backbone, then up and back down through the loop created. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Shachi12_837.JPG/460px-Shachi12_837.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Shachi12_837.JPG/760px-Shachi12_837.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Move the knot up to the bend in the straw, layering on top of the first knot created with the other wide stick. Tug gently on the bottom of the wide stick to tighten the knot. Both wide sticks and the stand should be pointing in the same direction. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Shachi13_596.JPG/460px-Shachi13_596.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Shachi13_596.JPG/759px-Shachi13_596.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Gently fold the wide sticks upward on their respective sides. This will position them away from the stand slightly, so that you can keep tying the body of the orca. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Shachi15_11.JPG/460px-Shachi15_11.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Shachi15_11.JPG/759px-Shachi15_11.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Begin tying again. Grab the first wide stick you tied. Pull it under the backbone, then pull up and draw back down through the loop created. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Shachi16_834.JPG/460px-Shachi16_834.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Shachi16_834.JPG/759px-Shachi16_834.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Tug gently on the wide strip to tighten the knot once it's at the bend in the straw.

steps.headline: Tie the other wide strip again.
steps.description:
Grab the second wide strip. Pull it under the backbone, then upward and back down through the loop created. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Shachi18_664.JPG/460px-Shachi18_664.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Shachi18_664.JPG/759px-Shachi18_664.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Tug gently on the wide strip to tighten the knot once it's at the bend in the straw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Shachi19_671.jpg/460px-Shachi19_671.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Shachi19_671.jpg/759px-Shachi19_671.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Again, both wide strips and the stand should be facing the same direction.

steps.headline: Repeat the knotting and tightening process three to four times.
steps.description:
Fold the two wide strips upward and away from the stand again. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Shachi22_558.JPG/460px-Shachi22_558.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Shachi22_558.JPG/759px-Shachi22_558.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Fold the first wide stick, then the other, in the same motion - looping under the backbone, then up and pulling down through the loop.

steps.headline: Create the pectoral fins.
steps.description:
The fins on each side of the orca are called pectoral fins, or pec fins, and they're used for steering. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi25_811.JPG/459px-Shachi25_811.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi25_811.JPG/759px-Shachi25_811.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.9142857142857,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Back view {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Shachi26_268.JPG/460px-Shachi26_268.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Shachi26_268.JPG/760px-Shachi26_268.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Position the orca standing on the two wide sticks left from folding and tying in the previous steps. You might have to bend the sticks a bit to get them into the right position. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Shachi27_425.JPG/460px-Shachi27_425.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Shachi27_425.JPG/760px-Shachi27_425.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut a small curved half moon on one fin. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Shachi28_63.JPG/460px-Shachi28_63.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Shachi28_63.JPG/759px-Shachi28_63.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut the same shape on the other side. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Shachi29_776.JPG/460px-Shachi29_776.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Shachi29_776.JPG/760px-Shachi29_776.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Pull away the pieces around the curved cuts. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Shachi30_821.JPG/460px-Shachi30_821.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Shachi30_821.JPG/760px-Shachi30_821.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Feather cut down the length of each pectoral fin.

steps.headline: Create the bend in the body.
steps.description:
Position the orca in your hands, with the short part of the straw away from your hold. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Shachi32_817.JPG/460px-Shachi32_817.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Shachi32_817.JPG/759px-Shachi32_817.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Bend the short part of the straw around to mold the body shape.

steps.headline: Cut the tail fin.
steps.description:
{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Shachi33_190.JPG/460px-Shachi33_190.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Shachi33_190.JPG/759px-Shachi33_190.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut a triangle into the short end of the straw. Remove the part that becomes unattached. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Shachi34_815.JPG/460px-Shachi34_815.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Shachi34_815.JPG/759px-Shachi34_815.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}As with the pectoral fin, feather cut the tail once it's in shape.

steps.headline: Cut the backbone.
steps.description:
Remove the remaining backbone around which you folded the wide sticks by cutting. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Shachi36_815.JPG/460px-Shachi36_815.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Shachi36_815.JPG/759px-Shachi36_815.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Admire your completed orca.

steps.headline: Add eyes.
steps.description: You can stick small googly eyes onto the head using a tiny drop of glue.

The short end will be the tail, while the two long, thin pieces will be the stand (stick in the diagram) and the backbone. You'll fold the long, wide pieces to make the body of the orca. It might help you to print this off to follow. Additionally, you might want to use a straw with colored lines running down the side for your first try. Locate the bend in the straw. With the straw flat, cut a thin strip off one side, making sure you cut both layers of the straw. The other thin stick will be the backbone. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Shachi9_933.JPG/460px-Shachi9_933.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Shachi9_933.JPG/759px-Shachi9_933.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

As with the first wide stick, pull it under the backbone, then up and back down through the loop created. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Shachi12_837.JPG/460px-Shachi12_837.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Shachi12_837.JPG/760px-Shachi12_837.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut a triangle into the short end of the straw. Remove the part that becomes unattached. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Shachi34_815.JPG/460px-Shachi34_815.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Shachi34_815.JPG/759px-Shachi34_815.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}As with the pectoral fin, feather cut the tail once it's in shape. Cut the backbone. Remove the remaining backbone around which you folded the wide sticks by cutting. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Shachi36_815.JPG/460px-Shachi36_815.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Shachi36_815.JPG/759px-Shachi36_815.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Admire your completed orca. Add eyes. You can stick small googly eyes onto the head using a tiny drop of glue.
sentences: Note the terminology applying to each piece of the straw.
This diagram shows how the pieces of the straw will be used to make the orca.
The short end will be the tail, while the two long, thin pieces will be the stand (stick in the diagram) and the backbone.
You'll fold the long, wide pieces to make the body of the orca.
It might help you to print this off to follow.
Additionally, you might want to use a straw with colored lines running down the side for your first try.
Locate the bend in the straw.
For now, keep the bend in the closed position.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Shachi2_122.JPG/460px-Shachi2_122.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/1f/Shachi2_122.JPG/759px-Shachi2_122.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Flatten the straw.
Press down on each side of the bend to flatten the straw, running your fingers over the bend a few times.
Do not flatten the bend itself.
Cut out the backbone and stand.
Pinch the straw flat between your thumb and forefinger with one hand.
With the other hand, use scissors to cut out your first piece.
With the straw flat, cut a thin strip off one side, making sure you cut both layers of the straw.
(If you're using a lined straw, it might be useful to flatten the straw such that the thin backbone and stand pieces contain the lines.)

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Shachi4_183.JPG/460px-Shachi4_183.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/ae/Shachi4_183.JPG/758px-Shachi4_183.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Stop cutting when you reach the straw bend.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Shachi5_450.JPG/460px-Shachi5_450.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bf/Shachi5_450.JPG/760px-Shachi5_450.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut out another thin strip on the other side of the flattened straw.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Shachi6_929.JPG/460px-Shachi6_929.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Shachi6_929.JPG/759px-Shachi6_929.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Again, don't cut along the edge itself but right next to it.
You should be cutting two layers of straw, not one.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi7_204.JPG/460px-Shachi7_204.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi7_204.JPG/759px-Shachi7_204.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}There will be four "sticks" once you're done with cutting – two thin sticks and two wide sticks.
Begin tying the body of the orca.
First, take one of the thin sticks and bend it so that it's at a 90-degree angle to the straw.
This stick will be the stand.
The other thin stick will be the backbone.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Shachi9_933.JPG/460px-Shachi9_933.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/5d/Shachi9_933.JPG/759px-Shachi9_933.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Grab one of the wide sticks and pull it under the backbone, then up and back down through the loop created.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Shachi10_891.JPG/460px-Shachi10_891.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/24/Shachi10_891.JPG/759px-Shachi10_891.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Pull the knot created by the wide stick all the way up to the bend in the straw.
Tug gently on the bottom of the wide stick to tighten.
Tie the other wide stick.
As with the first wide stick, pull it under the backbone, then up and back down through the loop created.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Shachi12_837.JPG/460px-Shachi12_837.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/9d/Shachi12_837.JPG/760px-Shachi12_837.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Move the knot up to the bend in the straw, layering on top of the first knot created with the other wide stick.
Tug gently on the bottom of the wide stick to tighten the knot.
Both wide sticks and the stand should be pointing in the same direction.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Shachi13_596.JPG/460px-Shachi13_596.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/14/Shachi13_596.JPG/759px-Shachi13_596.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Gently fold the wide sticks upward on their respective sides.
This will position them away from the stand slightly, so that you can keep tying the body of the orca.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Shachi15_11.JPG/460px-Shachi15_11.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/e1/Shachi15_11.JPG/759px-Shachi15_11.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Begin tying again.
Grab the first wide stick you tied.
Pull it under the backbone, then pull up and draw back down through the loop created.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Shachi16_834.JPG/460px-Shachi16_834.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Shachi16_834.JPG/759px-Shachi16_834.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Tug gently on the wide strip to tighten the knot once it's at the bend in the straw.
Tie the other wide strip again.
Grab the second wide strip.
Pull it under the backbone, then upward and back down through the loop created.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Shachi18_664.JPG/460px-Shachi18_664.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/bd/Shachi18_664.JPG/759px-Shachi18_664.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Tug gently on the wide strip to tighten the knot once it's at the bend in the straw.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Shachi19_671.jpg/460px-Shachi19_671.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4f/Shachi19_671.jpg/759px-Shachi19_671.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Again, both wide strips and the stand should be facing the same direction.
Repeat the knotting and tightening process three to four times.
Fold the two wide strips upward and away from the stand again.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Shachi22_558.JPG/460px-Shachi22_558.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c6/Shachi22_558.JPG/759px-Shachi22_558.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Fold the first wide stick, then the other, in the same motion - looping under the backbone, then up and pulling down through the loop.
Create the pectoral fins.
The fins on each side of the orca are called pectoral fins, or pec fins, and they're used for steering.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi25_811.JPG/459px-Shachi25_811.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/54/Shachi25_811.JPG/759px-Shachi25_811.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":344,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":568.9142857142857,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"} Back view {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Shachi26_268.JPG/460px-Shachi26_268.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Shachi26_268.JPG/760px-Shachi26_268.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Position the orca standing on the two wide sticks left from folding and tying in the previous steps.
You might have to bend the sticks a bit to get them into the right position.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Shachi27_425.JPG/460px-Shachi27_425.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/13/Shachi27_425.JPG/760px-Shachi27_425.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut a small curved half moon on one fin.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Shachi28_63.JPG/460px-Shachi28_63.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Shachi28_63.JPG/759px-Shachi28_63.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut the same shape on the other side.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Shachi29_776.JPG/460px-Shachi29_776.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/9/92/Shachi29_776.JPG/760px-Shachi29_776.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Pull away the pieces around the curved cuts.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Shachi30_821.JPG/460px-Shachi30_821.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/77/Shachi30_821.JPG/760px-Shachi30_821.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Feather cut down the length of each pectoral fin.
Create the bend in the body.
Position the orca in your hands, with the short part of the straw away from your hold.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Shachi32_817.JPG/460px-Shachi32_817.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/57/Shachi32_817.JPG/759px-Shachi32_817.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Bend the short part of the straw around to mold the body shape.
Cut the tail fin.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Shachi33_190.JPG/460px-Shachi33_190.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fe/Shachi33_190.JPG/759px-Shachi33_190.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Cut a triangle into the short end of the straw.
Remove the part that becomes unattached.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Shachi34_815.JPG/460px-Shachi34_815.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/53/Shachi34_815.JPG/759px-Shachi34_815.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}As with the pectoral fin, feather cut the tail once it's in shape.
Cut the backbone.
Remove the remaining backbone around which you folded the wide sticks by cutting.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Shachi36_815.JPG/460px-Shachi36_815.JPG","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/fc/Shachi36_815.JPG/759px-Shachi36_815.JPG","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":569.1774891774892,"licensing":"

TOHGIN minako

License: Creative Commons


"}Admire your completed orca.
Add eyes.
You can stick small googly eyes onto the head using a tiny drop of glue.
